          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []

          name: "page_rendering",
          timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
          value: JSON.stringify({
            time: performance?.now()
          })
        })
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push page render event:", error)

Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. \r\n \r\nDuring this CrowdCast, you will learn class="metadata Metadata_root__EZem9" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">CrowdCasts Monthly: You Have an Adversary Problem</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2013-10-16 14:09:38 UTC">Oct 16, 2013</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">6 likes</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">21,372<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="CrowdStrike" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-CrowdStrike-48x48.jpg?cb=1523357406" alt="CrowdStrike" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>CrowdStrike</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">You Have an Adversary Problem. Who&#x27;s Targeting You and Why? 
 
Nation-States, Hacktivists, Industrial Spies, and Organized Criminal Groups are attacking your enterprise on a daily basis. Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. 
 
During this CrowdCast, you will learn how to:

    Incorporate Actionable Intelligence into your existing enterprise security infrastructure 
    Quickly understand the capabilities and artifacts of targeted attacked tradecraft 
    Gain insight into the motivations and intentions of targeted attackers
    Make informed decisions based off of specific threat intelligence
</p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_more__ChrRK" data-testid="button" aria-label="Read more" data-cy="read-more-button"><span>Read more</span></button></div></div><div class="MetadataToolbar_root__x4cNG metadata-toolbar" data-cy="slideshow-toolbar"><div Today’s Speakers
ADAM MEYERS |
VP, INTELLIGENCE
Recognized speaker, trainer, and intelligence expert with 15+ years
of cyber security industry experience
10 years in the DIB supporting US GOV customers on topics
ranging from wireless, pen testing, IR, and malware analysis

@ADAM_CYBER

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

3

 " src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg" loading="lazy"/></div></a><div class="" id=":R46p7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R46p7d6"></div></div><div class="SlidePreviews_previewContainer__Qn8CH"><a aria-describedby="key-moment-3" class="SlidePreviews_momentContainer__zhQyW" href="#4" id="slide-preview-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R48p7d6:" popovertarget=":R48p7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R48p7d6"><span class="SlidePreviews_slideHeading__sTrgx slide-heading">4</span><div class="SlidePreviews_thumbnailContainer__QWeuK thumbnail-container" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540"><img class="SlidePreviews_thumbnail__6RNF6" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Today’s Speakers
MATT DAHL |
SENIOR ANALYST/ LEGAL COUNSEL
Cyber threat analyst focused on targeted intrusion activity

specific adversary activity

4

 " src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" loading="lazy"/></div></a><div class="" id=":R48p7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R48p7d6"></div></div><div class="SlidePreviews_previewContainer__Qn8CH"><a aria-describedby="key-moment-4" class="SlidePreviews_momentContainer__zhQyW" href="#5" id="slide-preview-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R4ap7d6:" popovertarget=":R4ap7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R4ap7d6"><span class="SlidePreviews_slideHeading__sTrgx slide-heading">5</span><div class="SlidePreviews_thumbnailContainer__QWeuK thumbnail-container" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540"><img class="SlidePreviews_thumbnail__6RNF6" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

CORSAIR
JACKAL?

Khlifa (XTnR3v0LT)

malicious activity, but also white hat
activity.

compromise databases at target

Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

these adversaries

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide4" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-3" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

4

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Between indicators

colludes with Anonymous
group XL3gi0n

20

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-20-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-20-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-20-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-20-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide21" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-20" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Adversary-Centric

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd1lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd1lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Cyphort">Cyphort</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In the digital age, one of the most effective ways to gather data and information about a potential enemy state is by infiltrating their ranks with malware. This webinar takes a deep drive into advanced persistent threat attacks performed by nation states. We will discuss various actors, government sponsored hackers, such as Duke, Bear, and Panda. Then we will look at malware created, like Regin, Elise, Flame, Equation Group, Babar, OnionDuke, and Dark Hotel.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11lh7d6:" popover="auto" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Splunk">Splunk</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document outlines a presentation on threat hunting with Splunk. The presenter is Ken Westin, a security strategist at Splunk with over 20 years of experience in technology and security. The agenda includes an overview of threat hunting basics and data sources, examining the cyber kill chain through a hands-on attack scenario using Splunk, and advanced threat hunting techniques including machine learning. Log-in credentials are provided for access to hands-on demo environments related to the presentation.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12lh7d6:" popover="auto" big data, artificial intelligence and machine learning in cyber i... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7lh7d6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AladdinDandisCISM">Aladdin Dandis</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the role of big data, artificial intelligence, and machine learning in cyber intelligence. It provides definitions of cyber intelligence and distinguishes between raw threat data and true threat intelligence. The document also outlines drivers for adopting AI-based cybersecurity technologies, including accelerating incident detection and response as well as improving risk communication and situational awareness. A cyber intelligence framework is proposed that involves collecting security data from various sources, processing the data using machine learning algorithms, and generating reports and alerts. Challenges with implementing such a framework are also noted.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R18lh7d6:" popovertarget=":R18lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R18lh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/BenBoyd/threat-hunting-every-day-is-hunting-season"><span class="sr-only">Threat hunting - class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/null0x00">n|u - The Open Security Community</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework, which is a knowledge base of adversary behaviors and tactics collected from real-world observations. It describes how the framework categorizes behaviors using tactics, techniques, and procedures. The framework can be used for threat intelligence, detection and analytics, adversary emulation, and assessment and engineering. The document provides examples of how organizations can map their detection capabilities and data sources to techniques in the framework to improve visibility of attacks. It cautions against misusing the framework as a checklist rather than taking a threat-informed approach.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1alh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1alh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1alh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/what-is-cyber-security-introduction-to-cyber-security-cyber-security-training-edureka/118299670"><span class="sr-only">What is Cyber Security? SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdclh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbdclh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdclh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdclh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdclh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/asfakian">Andreas Sfakianakis</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Title: Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence!


Abstract: Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI)! During this presentation, we will discuss about some of the basic concepts within CTI domain and we will have a look at the current threat landscape as observed from the trenches. The presentation is split into 3 parts: a) Intro to CTI, b) A view at the current threat landscape, and c) CTI analyst skillset.


Short Bio: Andreas Sfakianakis is a Cyber Threat Intelligence and Incident Response professional and works for Standard and Poors&#x27; CTI team. He is also a member of ENISA’s CTI Stakeholders’ Group and Incident Response Working Group. He is the author of a number of CTI reports and an instructor of CTI. In the past, Andreas has worked within the Financial and Oil &amp; Gas sectors as well as an external reviewer for European Commission. Andreas&#x27; Twitter handle is @asfakian and his website is www.threatintel.eu </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1clh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1clh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-12" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1dlh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1dlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1dlh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/from-theory-to-practice-how-my-attack-perspectives-have-changed/241296666"><span class="sr-only">From Theory to Practice: How My ATTACK Perspectives Have Changed</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:12" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="From Theory to Practice: How My ATTACK Perspectives Have Changed" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/katienickels-attckcon11dec2020pdf1-210113200918-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/katienickels-attckcon11dec2020pdf1-210113200918-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">From Theory to Practice: How My ATTACK Perspectives Have Changed</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save From Theory to Practice: How My ATTACK Perspectives Have Changed for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbddlh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbddlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbddlh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour December 2020

By Katie Nickels, Director of Intelligence, Red Canary

Good analysts (and good human beings) change their minds based on new information. In this presentation, Katie will share how her perspectives on ATT&amp;CK have changed since moving from ATT&amp;CK team member to ATT&amp;CK end-user. She will discuss how her ideas about coverage, procedures, and detection creation have evolved and why those perspectives matter. Katie will also share practical examples from observed threats to help explain the nuances of her perspectives. Attendees should expect to leave this presentation with a better understanding of how to handle challenges they’re likely to face when navigating their own ATT&amp;CK journey.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Business case for information security program for later" role="switch" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/WilliamGodwin1">William Godwin</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document presents a business case for establishing an information security program. It outlines the background, value, scope, and components of the program. The program aims to safeguard corporate information assets, establish security standards, comply with regulations, and align IT services with business needs. It involves categorizing data, determining risk appetite, analyzing business impacts, developing a security strategy and plans, and implementing controls. The goal is to effectively manage risks and threats, drive process maturity over time, and provide continuous improvements.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1flh7d6:" popover="auto" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Marlabs">Marlabs</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence is a process in which information from different sources is collected, then analyzed to identify and detect threats against any environment. The information collected could be evidence-based knowledge that could support the context, mechanism, indicators, or implications about an already existing threat against an environment, and/or the knowledge about an upcoming threat that could potentially affect the environment. Credit: Marlabs Inc</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1glh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1glh7d6"></div><div class="separator types of cyber criminals and cybersecurity specialists. It describes common cybersecurity threats like hacking, malware, and data breaches that can affect individuals, businesses, and organizations. The document also examines factors that contribute to the spread of cybercrime, such as software vulnerabilities, mobile devices, and the growth of internet-connected devices and large datasets. Intelligent Threat Hunting</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Bsides 2019 - Intelligent Threat Hunting for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdilh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbdilh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdilh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdilh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdilh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/DhruvMajumdar">Dhruv Majumdar</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document outlines an overview of intelligent threat hunting presented by Dhruv Majumdar. It discusses the basics of threat hunting, including that it is a proactive and iterative process to detect threats that evade existing security solutions. It provides a threat hunting recipe and describes important data sources and skills needed like host analysis, network analysis, and threat intelligence. It also walks through an attack scenario and things to look for at different stages of an attack lifecycle. Finally, it concludes with the growing demand for threat hunters and recommendations on how to get started with threat hunting.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ilh7d6:" popover="auto" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/cisoplatform7">Priyanka Aash</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses approaches for cybersecurity portfolio management. It addresses questions around identifying necessary versus unnecessary security products, gaps and overlaps in an existing portfolio, and defining a security strategy. Various frameworks are presented for conducting a structured portfolio analysis, including the OWASP Cyber Defense Matrix, CyberARM, Gartner&#x27;s Security Posture Assessment, and the US-CCU Cyber-Security Matrix. Effective use of an existing security portfolio involves identifying control overlaps, integrating products, automating workflows, replacing multiple products, optimizing configurations, and ensuring appropriate coverage of assets based on a threat model.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdklh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdklh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses using storytelling to increase understanding of cyber threats through ATT&amp;CK threat sightings. It describes the AC3 methodology for documenting threat actor tactics, techniques, and procedures with full context and observables. Different levels of abstraction and tools are used to translate threat sightings into various formats to ensure understanding across audiences. Maintaining defensive playbooks adapted from threat sightings helps continuous understanding and improvement of defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1klh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1klh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="seo-only">Repurposing adversarial tradecraft stems from the traditional sense of warfare and evolving your force to meet a threat.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1llh7d6:" popover="auto" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/arfanshahzad1">arfan shahzad</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses security frameworks and tools for information systems. It begins by explaining why systems are vulnerable, such as accessibility of networks and software/hardware problems. It then describes organizational frameworks for security, including risk assessment, security policies, identity management, disaster recovery planning, and information systems audits. Finally, it discusses tools for safeguarding resources, such as identity management software. The document provides an overview of securing information systems from multiple perspectives.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1mlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1mlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-22" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1nlh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1nlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1nlh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/leveraging-mitre-attck-speaking-the-common-language/150494688"><span class="sr-only">Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdnlh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbdnlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdnlh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdnlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdnlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/erikvanbuggenhout">Erik Van Buggenhout</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK is quickly gaining traction and is becoming an important standard to use to assess the overall cyber security posture of an organization. Tools like ATT&amp;CK Navigator facilitate corporate adoption and allow for a holistic overview on attack techniques and how the organization is preventing and detecting them. Furthermore, many vendors, technologies and open-source initiatives are aligning with ATT&amp;CK. Join Erik Van Buggenhout in this presentation, where he will discuss how MITRE ATT&amp;CK can be leveraged in the organization as part of your overall cyber security program, with a focus on adversary emulation.

Erik Van Buggenhout is the lead author of SANS SEC599 - Defeating Advanced Adversaries - Purple Team Tactics &amp; Kill Chain Defenses. Next to his activities at SANS, Erik is also a co-founder of NVISO, a European cyber security firm with offices in Brussels, Frankfurt and Munich.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1nlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1nlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-23" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1olh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1olh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1olh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/attcking-your-adversaries-operationalizing-cyber-intelligence-in-your-own-environment-for-better-sleep-and-a-safer-tomorrow/164054861"><span class="sr-only">ATT&amp;CKing Your Adversaries - Operationalizing cyber intelligence in your own ...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CKing Your Adversaries - It explains how to take cyber threat intelligence and map behaviors to the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework. Specific focus is given to the &quot;Process Doppelgänging&quot; technique, including understanding the behavior, potential detections, and emulating the behavior. The importance of fully emulating operations and expanding emulations through tools like Caldera is also covered.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1olh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1olh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdplh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdplh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Center for Threat-Informed Defense conducts collaborative R&amp;D projects to improve cyber defense. The Center&#x27;s work includes developing standardized adversary emulation plans, mapping vulnerabilities to adversary tactics and techniques, and creating tools to help organizations integrate threat information. All of the Center&#x27;s project outputs are made freely available to help defenders worldwide.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1plh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1plh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-25" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1qlh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1qlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1qlh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/using-attack-to-create-cyber-dbts-for-nuclear-power-plants/241296785"><span class="sr-only">Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:25" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckcon-final1-210113202045-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckcon-final1-210113202045-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdqlh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbdqlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdqlh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdqlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdqlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour December 2020

By Jacob Benjamin, Principal Industrial Consultant Dragos, INL, &amp; University of Idaho 

Design Basis Threat (DBT) is concept introduced by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). It is a profile of the type, composition, and capabilities of an adversary. DBT is the key input nuclear power plants use for the design of systems against acts of radiological sabotage and theft of special nuclear material. The NRC expects its licensees, nuclear power plants, to demonstrate that they can defend against the DBT. Currently, cyber is included in DBTs simply as a prescribed list of IT centric security controls. Using MITRE’s ATT&amp;CK framework, Cyber DBTs can be created that are specific to the facility, its material, or adversary activities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1qlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1qlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-26" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1rlh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1rlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1rlh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/purple-teaming-with-attck-x33fcon-2018/96390174"><span class="sr-only">Purple Teaming with ATT&amp;CK - x33fcon 2018</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:26" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Lex Crumpton leads MITRE&#x27;s defensive ATT&amp;CK efforts. In 2021, they added data sources and detections for monitoring processes interacting with LSASS.exe and detecting credential dumping tools. In 2022, they plan to add more detections and develop the Cyber Analytic Repository to share analytic knowledge. Crumpton invites attendees to learn more about defensive ATT&amp;CK on their website and contact them directly with any other questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1slh7d6:" popover="auto" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mgm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mgm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mgm9i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/null0x00">n|u - The Open Security Community</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework, which is a knowledge base of adversary behaviors and tactics collected from real-world observations. It describes how the framework categorizes behaviors using tactics, techniques, and procedures. The framework can be used for threat intelligence, detection and analytics, adversary emulation, and assessment and engineering. The document provides examples of how organizations can map their detection capabilities and data sources to techniques in the framework to improve visibility of attacks. It cautions against misusing the framework as a checklist rather than taking a threat-informed approach.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rh69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rh69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rh69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/what-is-cyber-security-introduction-to-cyber-security-cyber-security-training-edureka/118299670"><span class="sr-only">What is Cyber Security? Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mi69i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mi69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mi69i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mi69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mi69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/asfakian">Andreas Sfakianakis</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Title: Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence!


Abstract: Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI)! During this presentation, we will discuss about some of the basic concepts within CTI domain and we will have a look at the current threat landscape as observed from the trenches. The presentation is split into 3 parts: a) Intro to CTI, b) A view at the current threat landscape, and c) CTI analyst skillset.


Short Bio: Andreas Sfakianakis is a Cyber Threat Intelligence and Incident Response professional and works for Standard and Poors&#x27; CTI team. He is also a member of ENISA’s CTI Stakeholders’ Group and Incident Response Working Group. He is the author of a number of CTI reports and an instructor of CTI. In the past, Andreas has worked within the Financial and Oil &amp; Gas sectors as well as an external reviewer for European Commission. Andreas&#x27; Twitter handle is @asfakian and his website is www.threatintel.eu </span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ri69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ri69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rim9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rim9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rim9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour December 2020

By Katie Nickels, Director of Intelligence, Red Canary

Good analysts (and good human beings) change their minds based on new information. In this presentation, Katie will share how her perspectives on ATT&amp;CK have changed since moving from ATT&amp;CK team member to ATT&amp;CK end-user. She will discuss how her ideas about coverage, procedures, and detection creation have evolved and why those perspectives matter. Katie will also share practical examples from observed threats to help explain the nuances of her perspectives. Attendees should expect to leave this presentation with a better understanding of how to handle challenges they’re likely to face when navigating their own ATT&amp;CK journey.</span></div></div><div class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/WilliamGodwin1">William Godwin</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document presents a business case for establishing an information security program. It outlines the background, value, scope, and components of the program. The program aims to safeguard corporate information assets, establish security standards, comply with regulations, and align IT services with business needs. It involves categorizing data, determining risk appetite, analyzing business impacts, developing a security strategy and plans, and implementing controls. The goal is to effectively manage risks and threats, drive process maturity over time, and provide continuous improvements.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjm9i7d6:" popover="auto" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mk69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mk69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Marlabs">Marlabs</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence is a process in which information from different sources is collected, then analyzed to identify and detect threats against any environment. The information collected could be evidence-based knowledge that could support the context, mechanism, indicators, or implications about an already existing threat against an environment, and/or the knowledge about an upcoming threat that could potentially affect the environment. Credit: Marlabs Inc</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rk69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rk69i7d6"></div><div class="separator class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mkm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mkm9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MukeshChinta">Mukesh Chinta</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cybersecurity, including the different types of cyber criminals and cybersecurity specialists. It describes common cybersecurity threats like hacking, malware, and data breaches that can affect individuals, businesses, and organizations. The document also examines factors that contribute to the spread of cybercrime, such as software vulnerabilities, mobile devices, and the growth of internet-connected devices and large datasets. It outlines efforts to increase the cybersecurity workforce through frameworks, certifications, and professional development opportunities for cybersecurity experts.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rkm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rkm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rl69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rl69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rl69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-2019-intelligent-threat-hunting/137567151"><span class="sr-only">Bsides 2019 - Intelligent Threat Hunting</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:9" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Bsides 2019 - Intelligent Threat Hunting</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Bsides 2019 - Intelligent Threat Hunting for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5ml69i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5ml69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5ml69i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5ml69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5ml69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/DhruvMajumdar">Dhruv Majumdar</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document outlines an overview of intelligent threat hunting presented by Dhruv Majumdar. It discusses the basics of threat hunting, including that it is a proactive and iterative process to detect threats that evade existing security solutions. It provides a threat hunting recipe and describes important data sources and skills needed like host analysis, network analysis, and threat intelligence. It also walks through an attack scenario and things to look for at different stages of an attack lifecycle. Finally, it concludes with the growing demand for threat hunters and recommendations on how to get started with threat hunting.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rl69i7d6:" popover="auto" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/cisoplatform7">Priyanka Aash</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses approaches for cybersecurity portfolio management. It addresses questions around identifying necessary versus unnecessary security products, gaps and overlaps in an existing portfolio, and defining a security strategy. Various frameworks are presented for conducting a structured portfolio analysis, including the OWASP Cyber Defense Matrix, CyberARM, Gartner&#x27;s Security Posture Assessment, and the US-CCU Cyber-Security Matrix. Effective use of an existing security portfolio involves identifying control overlaps, integrating products, automating workflows, replacing multiple products, optimizing configurations, and ensuring appropriate coverage of assets based on a threat model.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rlm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" It then describes organizational frameworks for security, including risk assessment, security policies, identity management, disaster recovery planning, and information systems audits. Finally, it discusses tools for safeguarding resources, such as identity management software. The document provides an overview of securing information systems from multiple perspectives.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rn69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rn69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-14" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rnm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rnm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rnm9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/leveraging-mitre-attck-speaking-the-common-language/150494688"><span class="sr-only">Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mnm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mnm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mnm9i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mnm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mnm9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/erikvanbuggenhout">Erik Van Buggenhout</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK is quickly gaining traction and is becoming an important standard to use to assess the overall cyber security posture of an organization. Tools like ATT&amp;CK Navigator facilitate corporate adoption and allow for a holistic overview on attack techniques and how the organization is preventing and detecting them. Furthermore, many vendors, technologies and open-source initiatives are aligning with ATT&amp;CK. Join Erik Van Buggenhout in this presentation, where he will discuss how MITRE ATT&amp;CK can be leveraged in the organization as part of your overall cyber security program, with a focus on adversary emulation.

Erik Van Buggenhout is the lead author of SANS SEC599 - Defeating Advanced Adversaries - Purple Team Tactics &amp; Kill Chain Defenses. Next to his activities at SANS, Erik is also a co-founder of NVISO, a European cyber security firm with offices in Brussels, Frankfurt and Munich.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rnm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rnm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-15" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Ro69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Ro69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Ro69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/attcking-your-adversaries-operationalizing-cyber-intelligence-in-your-own-environment-for-better-sleep-and-a-safer-tomorrow/164054861"><span class="sr-only">ATT&amp;CKing Your Adversaries - Operationalizing cyber intelligence in your own ...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="ATT&amp;CKing Your Adversaries - Operationalizing cyber intelligence in your own ..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/bsideslvattck-190815151425-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">ATT&amp;CKing Your Adversaries - Operationalizing cyber intelligence in your own ...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CKing Your Adversaries - Operationalizing cyber intelligence in your own ... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mo69i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mo69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mo69i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mo69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mo69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JamieWilliams130">JamieWilliams130</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses operationalizing cyber threat intelligence by emulating adversary behaviors. It explains how to take cyber threat intelligence and map behaviors to the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework. Specific focus is given to the &quot;Process Doppelgänging&quot; technique, including understanding the behavior, potential detections, and emulating the behavior. The importance of fully emulating operations and expanding emulations through tools like Caldera is also covered.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ro69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ro69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rom9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rom9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rom9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/projects-to-impact-operationalizing-work-from-the-center/251521747"><span class="sr-only">Projects to Impact- Operationalizing Work from the Center</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Projects to Impact- Operationalizing Work from the Center</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Projects to Impact- Operationalizing Work from the Center for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mom9i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mom9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mom9i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mom9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mom9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Center for Threat-Informed Defense conducts collaborative R&amp;D projects to improve cyber defense. The Center&#x27;s work includes developing standardized adversary emulation plans, mapping vulnerabilities to adversary tactics and techniques, and creating tools to help organizations integrate threat information. All of the Center&#x27;s project outputs are made freely available to help defenders worldwide.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rom9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rom9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rp69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rp69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rp69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/using-attack-to-create-cyber-dbts-for-nuclear-power-plants/241296785"><span class="sr-only">Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckcon-final1-210113202045-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckcon-final1-210113202045-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mp69i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mp69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mp69i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mp69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mp69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour December 2020

By Jacob Benjamin, Principal Industrial Consultant Dragos, INL, &amp; University of Idaho 

Design Basis Threat (DBT) is concept introduced by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). It is a profile of the type, composition, and capabilities of an adversary. DBT is the key input nuclear power plants use for the design of systems against acts of radiological sabotage and theft of special nuclear material. The NRC expects its licensees, nuclear power plants, to demonstrate that they can defend against the DBT. Currently, cyber is included in DBTs simply as a prescribed list of IT centric security controls. Using MITRE’s ATT&amp;CK framework, Cyber DBTs can be created that are specific to the facility, its material, or adversary activities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rp69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rpm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rpm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rpm9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/purple-teaming-with-attck-x33fcon-2018/96390174"><span class="sr-only">Purple Teaming with ATT&amp;CK - x33fcon 2018</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Purple Teaming with ATT&amp;CK - x33fcon 2018" class="seo-only">Presentation slides presented by Cody Thomas and Christopher Korban at x33fcon 2018 about how to jumpstart your purple teaming with the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework, and accompanying Adversary Emulation Plans</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rpm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Lex Crumpton leads MITRE&#x27;s defensive ATT&amp;CK efforts. In 2021, they added data sources and detections for monitoring processes interacting with LSASS.exe and detecting credential dumping tools. In 2022, they plan to add more detections and develop the Cyber Analytic Repository to share analytic knowledge. Crumpton invites attendees to learn more about defensive ATT&amp;CK on their website and contact them directly with any other questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rq69i7d6:" popover="auto" Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:16 / 9;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div Intelligence Operations</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img Attribution of Russian Intelligence Operations</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Bear Hunting: History and Attribution of Russian Intelligence Operations for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mkmai7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mkmai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mkmai7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mkmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mkmai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Learn about the history of Russian intelligence influence operations and the cyber actors implementing them today.

In June 2016, CrowdStrike exposed unprecedented efforts by Russian intelligence services to interfere in the U.S. election via the hacking and subsequent leaking of information from political organizations and individuals. Election manipulation was not a new activity for the Russians - they have engaged in these influence operations consistently for the better part of the last two decades inside and outside of Russia.

In this CrowdCast, CrowdStrike experts Adam Meyers, VP of Intelligence, and Dmitri Alperovitch, Co-Founder &amp; CTO, will provide a detailed overview of the history of Russian intelligence influence operations going back decades and provide a deep dive overview of various BEAR (including FANCY BEAR AND COZY BEAR) intrusion sets and their tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). They will also discuss the considerable attribution evidence that CrowdStrike has collected from a variety of investigations into their operations and lay out the case for the Russian government connection to these hacks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rkmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rkmai7d6"></div><div class="separator aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5ml6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":R5ml6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5ml6ai7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5ml6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5ml6ai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/socradar">SOCRadar</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Canada’s cybersecurity risks are escalating, with finance and insurance industries making up 12.66% of dark web targets. Ransomware attacks continue to threaten the manufacturing sector, representing 21.11% of cases. LockBit leads the ransomware groups, responsible for 30.3% of attacks. Additionally, stealer logs expose over 208,000 email-password combinations, putting critical systems and sensitive data at risk.

Phishing threats have surged, with cryptocurrency-related attacks comprising 31.66% of incidents. Meanwhile, Canada faced over 110,000 DDoS attacks, signaling the urgent need for organizations to bolster defenses. Threat actors are increasingly leveraging stolen credentials and targeting vulnerable industries.

SOCRadar’s proactive threat intelligence solutions empower Canadian organizations to stay ahead of evolving cyber threats. Detect dark web activities, mitigate ransomware risks, and safeguard your assets with real-time monitoring. Download the full CISO brief now to secure your organization’s future.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rl6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start"
